awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Laboratory Studies on the Chemical Characterization of Atmospheric Emission Sources and their Oxidative Evolution using Novel Instrumentation
awd_abstract_narration:
1554061
Williams

Pollutants emitted to the atmosphere have a wide array of natural and anthropogenic origins. These pollutants almost immediately undergo oxidative aging processes that transform their molecular composition, ultimately influencing their fate. Vapor and particle pollutants, either emitted directly or formed from atmospheric photochemistry, have detrimental health impacts and can alter the climate. This proposed project will specifically look at organic compounds which comprise a major fraction of air and particulate pollution. To understand the health and climate impacts of specific emission sources, it is necessary to assign these pollutants to their sources of origin. This project will address improved measurement methods and focused laboratory studies to obtain detailed chemical composition of source-specific gases and particles as they undergo oxidative evolution in the atmosphere.

The primary goal of this project is to advance the understanding of the sources and transformation of organics emitted to the atmosphere through (1) creation of new in-situ instrumentation for chemical characterization of gases and particles, (2) controlled laboratory studies of the emissions and gas-to-particle formation pathways/potential from simple precursor vapors to realistic complex sources, (3) development of an open-access and searchable mass spectral and source profile database, and (4) integrated education and outreach activities including an academia/industry research experience program for undergraduates and direct research involvement from grade 6-12 students as part of a Peer Mentoring Pipeline Program. The current understanding of the chemicals released from natural and anthropogenic emission sources is limited, and the knowledge of the subsequent chemical transformations of these chemicals that occur while in the atmosphere is even more limited. At the conclusion of this project, metrics will be available for incorporation in model simulations and for field observation interpretation on volatility- and polarity-resolved source-specific chemical composition at the molecular and compound-class level. Additionally, new parameterizations, reaction mechanisms, and gas-to-particle aerosol production yields will be provided for a variety atmospheric oxidants (e.g., OH, O3, NO3) at different concentrations, for a variety of sources (e.g., single gases of differing volatilities and chemical functionality, simple mixtures, complex real sources), with consideration of other atmospheric variables (e.g., NOx and SO2 additions, seed particle types, and humidity levels). New instrumentation will be produced that extends chemical characterization of these emissions across a range of volatilities (from the most volatile gases to the least volatile condensed-phase material), offering new insights on specific atmospheric transformation pathways and fates of these materials. A new academia/industry research experience program in Atmospheric Science and Technology will offer undergraduate students an opportunity to work in both settings, helping to guide their career paths through first-hand experience. This will strengthen academic/industry connections and advance the field. In addition, grade 6-12 students will play a direct role in laboratory studies through the Peer Mentoring Pipeline Program.

por.por_cntn:
Through this CAREER award, improved measurement methods for the chemical and physical characterization of atmospheric organic particles and phase-partitioning vapors were developed.  Specific developments include: multiple versions of a semivolatile collection system for the Thermal desorption Aerosol GC/MS (TAG) instrument, an improved heating/cooling system for the volatility and polarity separator (VAPS), new data analysis methods for a custom-designed tandem differential mobility analyzer (TDMA), and customization of a potential aerosol mass (PAM) photoreactor for controlled laboratory studies of atmospheric aging processes.

A wide range of lab and field measurements have been conducted to characterize various atmospheric pollutant sources and transformation processes.  Specific sources of interest included biomass burning, coal combustion, electronic cigarette emissions and aging, secondary aerosol formation from biogenic precursors, and common indoor sources such as food cooking, candles and incense burning.  Chemical profiles have been recorded and included in beta-versions of open-access searchable databases specific to each measurement method.  Future ambient measurements can be directly compared to all database components to identify best matches with previously recorded lab and field studies.  Included in lab studies were controlled atmospheric aging experiments and phase-partitioning experiments that can help to identify or predict atmospheric processes that transform the chemical and physical properties of emissions.  A final method was developed to analyze offline samples that can be easily obtained from challenging access locations and furthers our potential to record a diverse range of source types to the chemical databases. COVID restrictions and local needs during this project drove our response to perform particle filtration tests for improvised respirators.

A peer mentoring pipeline was expanded to engage high school students, undergraduate, and graduate students in research, instruction, and mentorship activities.  An industry internship opportunity was piloted, resulting in an undergraduate continuing in the field with a prestigious graduate opportunity.  Class modules were developed to incorporate training activities for atmospheric research and equipment operation.

This project engaged one PI, one K-12 teacher, one Postdoctoral researcher, 3 education and outreach specialists, 6 PhD students, 16 Undergraduate students, and 2 High School students with research opportunities including lab and field studies, instrumentation and software development, data analysis, manuscript publication, and conference presentations for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students.  The project was structured to offer peer-mentorship across the various levels of experience, and provided interaction between academia and industry.

Results have been disseminated through manuscript publication (6 to-date, several more in-preparation), conference presentations by graduate, undergraduate, and high school students (36 presentations to-date), and in classroom teaching (especially the PI's course on Atmospheric Science & Climate).  Additional presentations have been given through lectures at local High Schools, prison presentations, science workshops, news media stories, seminars, interdisciplinary campus talks, and guest lectures in several courses.
